title: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of sporadic inclusion body myositis (sIBM), the most common acquired myopathy in adults over age 50. Includes diagnostic workup, differentiation from polymyositis and other myopathies, symptomatic management, trial of immunotherapy for dysphagia, fall prevention, and rehabilitation. Excludes hereditary inclusion body myopathy (hIBM/GNE myopathy), other inflammatory myopathies (dermatomyositis, polymyositis, IMNM -- see separate plans), and metabolic/toxic myopathies.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Primary muscle enzyme; characteristically mildly elevated in IBM (typically <10x ULN, often 1-3x ULN); higher elevation suggests alternative diagnosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (30-200 U/L); expect mild-moderate elevation (typically 300-1500 U/L)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function baseline; hepatic function for medication planning; AST/ALT may be mildly elevated from muscle source
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; mild AST/ALT elevation may reflect muscle rather than liver injury

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline blood counts; infection screen; lymphocyte subset if considering immunotherapy trial
Muscle enzyme that may be elevated when CK is normal or mildly elevated; supportive of myopathic process
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (<7.7 U/L); may be mildly elevated

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Inflammatory marker; usually normal or mildly elevated in IBM (minimal systemic inflammation)
Inflammatory marker; usually normal in IBM
Muscle enzyme; may be mildly elevated
Baseline; relevant if corticosteroid trial considered

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: IBM-specific biomarker; sensitivity ~60%, specificity ~70-90%; supports IBM diagnosis when positive; also found in Sjogren and SLE (lower specificity in those contexts)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative in healthy controls; positive supports IBM diagnosis

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Exclude polymyositis, dermatomyositis, IMNM; anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2, anti-MDA5, anti-SRP, anti-HMGCR all expected negative in IBM
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative for myositis-specific antibodies (positive suggests alternative diagnosis)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Exclude anti-synthetase syndrome (arthritis, ILD, mechanic's hands, Raynaud)
Exclude immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM); anti-SRP causes severe proximal weakness with very high CK
Exclude statin-associated immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy; important if statin exposure history
Connective tissue disease overlap screen; may be positive in IBM (~20%) but nonspecific
Sjogren syndrome overlap screen; Sjogren can coexist with IBM
B12 deficiency causes neuropathy that may compound weakness; common in older adults
Folate deficiency; baseline if methotrexate trial considered
Deficiency common in older adults; worsens muscle weakness and fall risk; relevant for bone health
Diabetes screen; diabetic neuropathy may compound weakness; relevant if steroid trial
Screen before immunotherapy trial (IVIG, rituximab) for reactivation risk
Screen before immunotherapy; HCV-associated myopathy in differential
HIV-associated myopathy in differential; screen before immunosuppression
Baseline before IVIG trial; IgA deficiency is contraindication to standard IVIG

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for GNE myopathy (hereditary IBM)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If onset age <50, autosomal recessive family history, or atypical features (no inflammation on biopsy); GNE gene mutation causes hereditary inclusion body myopathy
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal (no GNE mutation); positive suggests hIBM, not sporadic IBM

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for hereditary myopathy panel
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If biopsy atypical or diagnosis uncertain; includes VCP, SQSTM1, HNRNPA1, HNRNPA2B1 (multisystem proteinopathy genes), GNE, desmin, myotilin, ZASP
If rapid progression atypical for IBM; consider paraneoplastic myopathy
If biopsy shows mitochondrial abnormalities (COX-negative fibers common in IBM but also in mitochondrial myopathy); distinguish primary mitochondrial disease
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; pathogenic mutation suggests mitochondrial myopathy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Late-onset Pompe disease in differential (proximal weakness, respiratory insufficiency, mildly elevated CK)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal enzyme activity; reduced activity suggests Pompe disease

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Paraproteinemia screen; monoclonal gammopathy-associated neuropathy/myopathy in older adults
Baseline if considering complement-modulating therapies; overlap autoimmune conditions
Overlap myositis-scleroderma phenotype if scleroderma features present

Essential/First-line.item: MRI thighs with and without contrast (bilateral) (CPT 73721)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within first 1-2 weeks of evaluation; guides biopsy site
Essential/First-line.target: IBM-characteristic pattern: selective fatty replacement and atrophy of quadriceps (especially vastus lateralis and medialis with relative sparing of rectus femoris), medial gastrocnemius, and forearm flexor muscles; T2/STIR edema in active areas; asymmetric involvement
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Essential/First-line.timing: During initial workup; essential for diagnosis
Essential/First-line.target: IBM-characteristic: mixed myopathic AND neurogenic pattern (short-duration and long-duration MUAPs); fibrillations and positive sharp waves (irritable myopathy); increased insertional activity; NCS usually normal (may show mild sensory neuropathy in older patients)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None significant; avoid anticoagulated limbs for needle EMG

Essential/First-line.target: Baseline; IBM rarely causes ILD (unlike DM/PM); screen for aspiration pneumonia if dysphagia present

Extended.item: MRI forearms with and without contrast (bilateral)
Extended.timing: If finger flexor weakness prominent; helps confirm IBM pattern
Extended.target: Selective atrophy and fatty infiltration of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP); relative sparing of flexor digitorum superficialis; asymmetric
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Extended.timing: If dysphagia present or suspected; cricopharyngeal dysfunction common in IBM (40-80%)
Extended.target: Cricopharyngeal bar; impaired pharyngeal transit; vallecular and piriform sinus residue; aspiration or penetration

Extended.timing: If respiratory symptoms present; IBM can cause respiratory muscle weakness in advanced disease
Extended.target: FVC >80% predicted; DLCO >80% predicted; mild restrictive pattern in advanced disease from respiratory muscle weakness

Extended.timing: Baseline cardiac assessment in older patients
Extended.target: Normal sinus rhythm; no conduction abnormalities

Extended.item: Whole-body MRI or MRI pelvis/upper extremities
Extended.timing: Comprehensive assessment of muscle involvement pattern; document disease extent for monitoring
Extended.target: Selective atrophy pattern consistent with IBM; quadriceps, medial gastrocnemius, FDP, FCR preferentially affected; asymmetric
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Rare/Specialized.timing: After MRI guidance; within 2-4 weeks of evaluation; biopsy affected (but not end-stage fatty) muscle; avoid recently EMG'd muscle on ipsilateral side
Rare/Specialized.target: IBM-diagnostic findings: rimmed vacuoles (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions with basophilic rim); endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T-cell invasion of non-necrotic fibers; congophilic (Congo red positive) amyloid deposits under fluorescence; p62-positive aggregates; TDP-43 positive inclusions; 15-18nm tubulofilaments on electron microscopy; mitochondrial changes (COX-negative fibers, ragged red fibers)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Non-invasive assessment of muscle echogenicity; can guide biopsy site
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased echogenicity in affected muscles; selective quadriceps and FDP involvement; asymmetric

Rare/Specialized.timing: If dysphagia evaluation warrants motility assessment beyond MBSS
Rare/Specialized.target: Cricopharyngeal dysfunction; reduced pharyngeal contraction; abnormal UES relaxation

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN pain; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment); IV alternative: 1000 mg IV q6h if NPO

Acute/Emergent.indication: VTE prevention in immobilized patients admitted with fall-related injuries or acute deconditioning

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start on admission if immobile

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Platelets q3 days; anti-Xa if renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Modest improvement in muscle strength and endurance in IBM (limited evidence); well-tolerated nutritional supplement

dosing.instructions: 5 g PO daily mixed in water or juice; no loading phase needed; take with meal

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function at baseline and q6 months; serum creatinine (will be mildly elevated from supplement, not nephrotoxicity)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Osteoporosis prevention in older adults with IBM at high fall risk; bone protection if corticosteroid trial

dosing.instructions: 70 mg PO weekly on empty stomach with full glass of water; remain upright 30 min after

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: GFR <35; esophageal disorders; inability to remain upright 30 min; hypocalcemia
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: DEXA at baseline and q2 years; renal function; calcium; dental exam (ONJ risk)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Bone health and fall prevention in older adults with IBM; vitamin D deficiency common and worsens muscle weakness

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium carbonate + Vitamin D 1000-1200 mg Ca + 1000-2000 IU D PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 1000-2000 IU PO daily; higher vitamin D doses if deficient (50,000 IU weekly x 8 weeks then maintenance)
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium carbonate + Vitamin D 1000-1200 mg Ca + 1000-2000 IU D PO

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Serum calcium; vitamin D level q3-6 months until replete

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain or painful cramps associated with IBM; concurrent peripheral neuropathy common in older adults

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg PO qHS; increase by 300 mg/day every 3-5 days; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; reduce dose if CrCl <60

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); respiratory depression risk in elderly
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; fall risk (critical in IBM patients); renal function for dose adjustment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain or muscle cramps if gabapentin not tolerated

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg PO BID; may increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg BID; reduce dose if CrCl <60

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); angioedema history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; fall risk; peripheral edema; weight gain; renal function

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation (immobility-related, common in IBM due to reduced activity)

dosing.instructions: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz liquid PO daily; adjust frequency based on response

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GERD management in patients with dysphagia; GI protection if aspirin or NSAID use

dosing.instructions: 20 mg PO daily; take 30 minutes before breakfast

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: PPI allergy; long-term use concerns (B12, Mg, bone density)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Magnesium if prolonged use; B12 level

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO daily; increase to 50 mg after 1 week; may titrate by 25-50 mg q2-4 weeks; max 200 mg/day

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily in elderly; increase to 10 mg after 1 week; max 20 mg/day (10 mg in age >65 per FDA)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; hyponatremia (SIADH, especially elderly); suicidality monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: IBM-related dysphagia unresponsive to conservative measures; NOT proven for limb weakness in IBM; limited evidence of transient swallowing improvement; time-limited trial (3-6 months) with objective assessment

dosing.instructions: 2 g/kg total divided over 2-5 days (e.g., 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days) every 4 weeks; assess dysphagia response objectively at 3 and 6 months; discontinue if no improvement

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: IgA deficiency (use IgA-depleted product); acute renal failure; recent thrombotic event; volume overload
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Vital signs q15min during first infusion; renal function (BUN, Cr) before and after; headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombotic events; hemolysis (haptoglobin, LDH, direct Coombs); MBSS at 3 and 6 months to assess dysphagia response

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative to IVIG for dysphagia management; patient self-administration at home; fewer systemic side effects than IVIG

dosing.instructions: Equivalent monthly dose to IVIG divided into weekly SC infusions; multiple sites simultaneously; train patient/caregiver on self-administration

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: IgA deficiency (use IgA-depleted product); acute renal failure; recent thrombotic event; inadequate SC tissue
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Local infusion site reactions; IgG trough levels; renal function; dysphagia response (MBSS q6 months)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Time-limited trial (12 weeks) ONLY if diagnosis uncertain and polymyositis remains in differential; most IBM patients do NOT respond; steroid myopathy may worsen weakness

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) as single morning dose; assess strength and CK at 4, 8, 12 weeks; taper and discontinue if no objective improvement by 12 weeks; steroid myopathy can WORSEN IBM weakness

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis; GI bleeding; strong clinical suspicion for IBM (avoid unnecessary trial)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose weekly; BP; weight; mood; bone density if >3 months; muscle strength (MMT) at 4, 8, 12 weeks to objectively assess response; CK trending

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Time-limited trial if polymyositis remains in differential and steroid trial inconclusive; NOT effective for IBM in clinical trials

dosing.instructions: Start 10-15 mg PO once weekly; folic acid 1 mg PO daily (except methotrexate day); assess at 3-6 months; discontinue if no objective improvement

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category X); hepatic disease; CrCl <30; active infection; pulmonary fibrosis; concurrent TMP-SMX
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC q2-4 weeks during titration then q8-12 weeks; LFTs q8-12 weeks; renal function; pulmonary symptoms; strength assessment q3 months

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Cricopharyngeal dysfunction causing dysphagia refractory to conservative measures; EMG-guided injection

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin injection (cricopharyngeal) 15-30 units Local injection

dosing.instructions: 15-30 units onabotulinumtoxinA injected into cricopharyngeus muscle under EMG or fluoroscopic guidance; effect onset 3-7 days; duration 3-6 months; may repeat
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin injection (cricopharyngeal) 15-30 units Local injection

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Infection at injection site; known hypersensitivity; myasthenia gravis (relative)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Dysphagia response; MBSS 2-4 weeks post-injection; transient worsening of swallow possible; aspiration risk monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe refractory cricopharyngeal dysphagia not responsive to botulinum toxin or IVIG; surgical division of cricopharyngeus muscle

dosing.instructions: Surgical myotomy of cricopharyngeus muscle by otolaryngology/head and neck surgeon; one-time procedure; can significantly improve swallowing in appropriately selected patients

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Poor surgical candidate; significant pharyngeal weakness (not just cricopharyngeal); respiratory failure risk
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-operative swallow assessment; wound healing; aspiration risk; MBSS 4-6 weeks post-operatively

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.item: No proven disease-modifying therapy for IBM
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: IBM has no FDA-approved or proven disease-modifying treatment; multiple clinical trials (arimoclomol, bimagrumab, rapamycin, natalizumab) have not demonstrated efficacy; management is supportive and symptomatic

doseOptions.orderSentence: No proven disease-modifying therapy for IBM N/A N/A

dosing.instructions: No disease-modifying therapy available; focus on symptomatic management, fall prevention, dysphagia management, and rehabilitation
dosing.orderSentence: No proven disease-modifying therapy for IBM N/A N/A

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Continued monitoring for emerging clinical trial opportunities; annual reassessment of functional status

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist for diagnostic confirmation, EMG interpretation, biopsy planning, and long-term disease management
Speech-language pathology for comprehensive swallow evaluation given high prevalence of cricopharyngeal dysfunction and aspiration risk in IBM (40-80% develop dysphagia)
Physical therapy for individualized exercise program, fall prevention strategies, gait training, and assistive device fitting given progressive quadriceps weakness and high fall risk
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, hand function optimization (grip aids, adaptive utensils), energy conservation, and home modification assessment given finger flexor weakness
Otolaryngology (ENT) for cricopharyngeal dysfunction evaluation, botulinum toxin injection consideration, and cricopharyngeal myotomy evaluation if dysphagia is severe and refractory
Nutrition/Dietetics for dysphagia diet modification (texture adaptation), weight management, protein optimization for muscle preservation, and nutritional supplementation
Pulmonology if respiratory symptoms develop (advanced IBM may cause respiratory muscle weakness); PFT monitoring in advanced disease
Physiatry (PM&R) for comprehensive rehabilitation planning, durable medical equipment prescription, and disability evaluation
Social work for disability evaluation assistance, insurance navigation, community resources, and caregiver support given progressive nature of IBM
Psychiatry/Psychology for adjustment to chronic progressive illness, depression screening, coping strategies, and cognitive behavioral therapy
Gastroenterology for PEG tube placement evaluation if severe dysphagia with weight loss and recurrent aspiration despite conservative measures and IVIG trial
Pain management if refractory musculoskeletal pain from compensatory movement patterns and joint stress
Palliative care for symptom management, goals of care discussion, and quality of life optimization in advanced IBM with significant disability
Genetic counseling if hereditary inclusion body myopathy (hIBM/GNE myopathy) suspected based on age <50, family history, or atypical features
Clinical trial coordinator for enrollment in IBM clinical trials (check clinicaltrials.gov for active studies)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if new difficulty breathing or worsening shortness of breath (may indicate aspiration pneumonia or respiratory muscle weakness)
Return to ED if choking episodes during eating or drinking, or inability to swallow medications (aspiration risk requiring urgent evaluation)
Return to ED if fall with head injury, inability to get up, or new severe pain (high fall risk due to quadriceps weakness)
Return to ED if fever with cough or difficulty breathing (may indicate aspiration pneumonia given dysphagia risk)
Expect slow but progressive weakness over years; IBM is a chronic condition without cure, but many patients remain ambulatory for 10-15 years after diagnosis
Use assistive devices as recommended by PT/OT (cane, walker, wheelchair) to prevent falls and maintain independence -- early adoption improves safety
Modify diet texture as recommended by speech therapist; avoid thin liquids if swallow evaluation shows aspiration risk; use thickened liquids and soft foods as directed
Sit upright during and for 30 minutes after meals to reduce aspiration risk; eat slowly and take small bites
Report any new difficulty swallowing, coughing during meals, or unintentional weight loss to neurology (may indicate worsening dysphagia requiring intervention)
Wear supportive footwear with non-slip soles; use grab bars in bathroom; remove loose rugs and floor obstacles to prevent falls
Do not drive if quadriceps weakness limits ability to safely brake or operate pedals; discuss driving safety with neurology and OT
Maintain regular exercise as tolerated -- supervised low-to-moderate intensity exercise is safe and may help maintain function longer; avoid extreme exertion or eccentric exercises
Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments (strength assessment and swallow monitoring essential to guide management)
Carry a medical identification card or bracelet indicating IBM diagnosis in case of emergency

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Supervised progressive resistance exercise program (moderate intensity) -- evidence supports safety and modest functional benefit in IBM; focus on non-atrophied muscle groups; 2-3 sessions per week
Low-impact aerobic exercise (stationary cycling, water-based exercise, swimming) to maintain cardiovascular fitness and slow deconditioning
High-protein diet (1.2-1.5 g/kg/day protein) to support muscle preservation and slow sarcopenia progression; adequate caloric intake to prevent weight loss
Home safety evaluation by OT to remove fall hazards, install grab bars, raised toilet seat, shower bench, stair rails, and adequate lighting
Annual influenza vaccination (inactivated) and pneumococcal vaccination per guidelines given aspiration risk and respiratory vulnerability
Fall prevention program including balance exercises, home modifications, medication review for fall-risk-increasing medications, and vision correction
Adequate hydration (minimum 1.5-2 L/day) to support muscle health and prevent constipation
Alcohol limitation as alcohol worsens muscle weakness and increases fall risk
Adequate sleep (7-9 hours) to support muscle recovery and overall health
Weight management to reduce load on weakened quadriceps and improve mobility; avoid obesity which accelerates functional decline
Vitamin D supplementation to maintain level >30 ng/mL for muscle and bone health; higher dose repletion if deficient
Assistive device progression planning with PT/OT: ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) for foot drop, cane, walker, wheelchair as needed for safety
Caregiver education on safe transfer techniques, fall management, and recognizing signs of aspiration to optimize home safety
Social engagement and meaningful activities adaptation to maintain quality of life despite progressive physical limitations

differential.features: Symmetric proximal weakness; typically subacute onset; higher CK (10-50x ULN); responsive to immunotherapy (steroids, steroid-sparing agents); no distal finger flexor weakness; no rimmed vacuoles on biopsy
differential.tests: CK (higher in PM); muscle biopsy (endomysial CD8+ invasion WITHOUT rimmed vacuoles or amyloid); EMG (purely myopathic, no neurogenic features); MSA panel (anti-Jo-1, anti-SRP); robust steroid response

differential.features: Characteristic skin findings (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, V-sign, shawl sign); symmetric proximal weakness; higher CK; responsive to immunotherapy; skin precedes or accompanies weakness
differential.tests: Skin examination; CK (higher); muscle biopsy (perifascicular atrophy, perivascular inflammation); MSA panel (anti-Mi-2, anti-MDA5, anti-TIF1-gamma, anti-NXP2); skin biopsy

differential.features: Very high CK (often >5000-10,000); severe symmetric proximal weakness; rapid progression; statin-associated or idiopathic; responsive to aggressive immunotherapy (IVIG, rituximab)
differential.tests: CK (much higher); anti-SRP or anti-HMGCR antibodies; muscle biopsy (necrotic/regenerating fibers with minimal inflammation, MAC deposition); dramatic CK response to IVIG/rituximab

differential.features: Earlier onset (variable); family history; progressive without inflammatory markers; symmetric proximal weakness; no finger flexor involvement typically; specific genetic subtypes
differential.tests: Genetic testing panel (>30 subtypes); CK (variable); muscle biopsy (dystrophic changes, absent/reduced protein on immunostaining, no rimmed vacuoles); no inflammation

differential.features: Fasciculations; upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski, spasticity); mixed UMN/LMN pattern; bulbar onset with dysarthria/dysphagia; more rapid progression; no sensory loss
differential.tests: EMG (widespread active denervation with fasciculations in multiple regions including thoracic paraspinals); normal or mildly elevated CK; no rimmed vacuoles on biopsy; clinical pattern of combined UMN + LMN signs

differential.features: Predominantly distal weakness; specific patterns per subtype; typically earlier onset; genetic basis; no inflammation on biopsy
differential.tests: Genetic testing; CK variable; muscle biopsy (myopathic changes without inflammation in most; Nonaka/GNE shows rimmed vacuoles but no inflammation); EMG purely myopathic

differential.features: Fatigable weakness (worse with repetitive use, improves with rest); ocular involvement (ptosis, diplopia); fluctuating symptoms; normal CK; intact muscle bulk
differential.tests: AChR/MuSK antibodies; repetitive nerve stimulation (decremental response); SFEMG (increased jitter); normal CK; ice pack test; edrophonium test

differential.features: Proximal weakness with fatigue; elevated CK (mild); hypothyroid symptoms (weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, bradycardia); delayed relaxation of reflexes
differential.tests: TSH (elevated); free T4 (low); CK normalizes with thyroid hormone replacement; no biopsy changes of IBM

differential.features: Temporal correlation with drug initiation; symmetric proximal weakness; CK may be elevated; improves after drug discontinuation
differential.tests: Medication history; CK trending after drug withdrawal; anti-HMGCR negative (if positive, diagnose IMNM instead); improvement within weeks to months of stopping offending drug

differential.features: Proximal weakness (especially hip girdle); respiratory muscle weakness (disproportionate to limb weakness); elevated CK (mild-moderate); autosomal recessive; enzyme replacement available
differential.tests: Acid alpha-glucosidase activity (dried blood spot -- reduced); GAA gene testing; muscle biopsy (vacuolar myopathy with PAS-positive material, acid phosphatase); disproportionate respiratory weakness

differential.features: Symmetric proximal AND distal weakness; sensory loss; areflexia; elevated CSF protein; demyelinating NCS; responsive to IVIG/steroids; no myopathic EMG pattern
differential.tests: NCS (demyelinating pattern: prolonged distal latencies, slow CV, conduction block, temporal dispersion); CSF protein elevated; normal CK; nerve biopsy if needed

differential.features: Asymmetric distal > proximal weakness; no UMN signs; no sensory loss; conduction block on NCS; anti-GM1 antibodies; responsive to IVIG
differential.tests: NCS (motor conduction block); anti-GM1 antibody; normal CK; EMG neurogenic pattern; IVIG-responsive

evidence.source: Expert consensus; standard of care for neuromuscular disorders

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; q6-12 months formal assessment; focus on quadriceps, hip flexors, finger flexors, wrist flexors
monitoring.action: If accelerated decline: reassess diagnosis; consider overlap myositis; repeat EMG/biopsy if atypical; adjust rehabilitation program
If rapid decline: reassess diagnosis; optimize hand therapy; update adaptive equipment

monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months in established IBM; more frequently if diagnosis uncertain or immunotherapy trial
monitoring.action: If CK >5x from baseline: evaluate for rhabdomyolysis (fall/injury), reconsider diagnosis, assess medication effects

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; formal MBSS q6-12 months if dysphagia present
monitoring.action: If worsening: SLP re-evaluation; diet modification; consider IVIG trial for dysphagia; ENT referral for botulinum toxin or myotomy; PEG tube discussion if severe

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; monthly if dysphagia present
monitoring.action: If weight loss >5% in 6 months: reassess dysphagia; nutrition consultation; calorie supplementation; PEG tube consideration

monitoring.frequency: Annually; q6 months if respiratory symptoms or FVC <80%
monitoring.action: If FVC declining or <60% predicted: pulmonology referral; assess need for nocturnal ventilatory support (BiPAP); sleep study

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; patient-reported fall diary
monitoring.action: If recurrent falls: PT reassessment; home safety re-evaluation; assistive device upgrade; medication review for fall-risk drugs

monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months; IBM Functional Rating Scale (IBMFRS) if available
monitoring.action: If accelerated functional decline: comprehensive reassessment; optimize PT/OT; reassess diagnosis if atypical

monitoring.frequency: Baseline in all IBM patients (older adults at fall risk); q2 years; sooner if steroid exposure
monitoring.action: If T-score <-2.5 (osteoporosis): bisphosphonate; calcium/vitamin D; endocrine referral; fall prevention is critical

monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months until replete, then annually
monitoring.action: If deficient (<20): high-dose repletion (50,000 IU weekly x 8 weeks); maintenance 2000-4000 IU daily; recheck in 3 months

monitoring.frequency: Annually minimum; more frequently if concerns
monitoring.action: If PHQ-9 >=10: assess safety; initiate antidepressant (sertraline or escitalopram); psychology/psychiatry referral

monitoring.frequency: Annually; q3-6 months if on gabapentin/pregabalin or creatine supplementation
monitoring.action: If declining: adjust renally-cleared medications; assess hydration; nephrology referral if progressive

disposition.criteria: Ambulatory (with or without assistive device); safe swallow (no active aspiration); adequate oral intake; pain controlled; fall risk assessed and mitigated; outpatient neuromuscular follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks; home safety adequate or modifications planned; understands return precautions

Fall-related injury requiring monitoring (fracture, head injury); aspiration pneumonia requiring IV antibiotics; new diagnosis requiring expedited inpatient workup (biopsy, EMG); severe dehydration or malnutrition from dysphagia; acute deconditioning with inability to safely function at home

Respiratory failure from aspiration pneumonia requiring ventilatory support; severe aspiration event with airway compromise; fall with traumatic brain injury or hemodynamic instability (rare, situational)

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for neuromuscular specialist not available locally; need for specialized muscle biopsy with neuromuscular pathology expertise; need for cricopharyngeal myotomy or advanced dysphagia intervention not available on-site
Significant functional decline from IBM with deconditioning; able to participate in 3 hours/day therapy; medically stable; post-fall with functional decline; benefit expected from intensive PT/OT

Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; unable to safely manage at home despite assistive devices; requires ongoing skilled nursing (wound care, PEG feeds, respiratory support); end-stage IBM with high care needs
